author: {'steamid': '76561198287194682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1647, 'last_played': 1534117103}
review:
This is a very good RPG that's only lightly overshadowed by EBF5, they're both very good games. 

EBF4 is a very cute story light fight heavy RPG, with the main complexity coming from the fact that every character can use approximately 20 attacks / spells, and there are also like 15 damage types that enemies can have their own resistances / weaknesses for. and if you want, you can crank the difficulty up by playing in a higher gamemode. And equipment can provide massive bonuses to all sorts of things. 

solid 9/10 RPG, better than most because the fights don't get repetitive that quickly and you don't need to grind much, as well as the complexity of the combat system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142106336', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1212, 'last_played': 1708980345}
review:
Unfortunately didn't grow up in a big RPG console era so my Mom playing Final Fantasy X gave me interest in the whole shebang. This is basically just Final Fantasy but a flash series with art I admire and adore, great music and uh, cat deities story!

Playing this and all the other originals back when I was younger on ArmorGames was such a treat, enjoyed my shitty laptop taking a full 2 minutes to have the final boss's attacks finish while I ran around my room hoping whether or not I'd live.

author: {'steamid': '76561198304992485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2395, 'last_played': 1710618944}
review:
Honestly my favorite in the series. EBF5 is the newer game, but with the 3.0 release and the polish of time, 4 is the one I prefer and find myself returning to. 

As the last in the core series before the reboot, it also is a nice conclusion to the story that really kicked off in 3. Anna is a fun character to play with, and works well as a more physically inclined support role compared to Lance. Dialogue is everything you could expect from a EBF game, and I really enjoy the challenge options and scaling. The scaling options are fine, but the real meat is in the 2.0/3.0 optional cheats/challenges, letting me breeze past all regular enemy fights, and other grinding, while also making the ultimate challenge when trying to get the stars on medals.

If you like 3, 4 is great, if you like 5, it has enough QoL that going back isn't that big of an issue, especially after the 3.0 update.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119642552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 7176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7176, 'last_played': 1710299927}
review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4, what a fun sequel to EBF3 and with the new add on of Anna the character to balance out the roster.
The music is awesome as always, heck I'm listening to it while making this review, thanks Phyrnna.
The battle system is great, reminiscent of the usual turn based JRPGs.
In it's entirety, the game is great though there are some nitpicks I have with it.

The armor and weapons in this game are very unbalanced, barely any poison/holy resistance for the guys or a lot of the armor and weapons have resistances that aren't useful. Barely any Syphon resistance with needing to use certain weapons like the Alchemist's Bow.
Granted I base my play style on how well resisted to the elements I can be so it can also be up to preference.
However the latest update of version 4.0.3 which adds 4 new weapons for each character (while fantastic) are not only stuck behind the top of Battle Mountain (late game area) which means you'll never use these new weapons unless you play New Game+.

I'd rate this game a 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561199189102456', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2931, 'last_played': 1709680944}
review:
Este juego es una gran joya un poco no apreciada, con sus mecÃ¡nicas clÃ¡sicas de un rpg basado en turnos (que cada uno quiere mas que otro), con su comedia bastante bien lograda, una dificultad la cual te enseÃ±a a aprenderte sus mecÃ¡nicas pero aun dÃ¡ndote la libertad de hacer lo que quieras con los cuatro protagonistas. lo que mas resalta en esta entrega en mi opiniÃ³n es lo bien apretado que esta todo el contenido, aprovechando cada parte del mapa para, no simplemente llenarlo con enemigos, sino que diÃ¡logos e interacciones que se sienten genuinas entre ellos.
Como semi-punto final me gustarÃ­a decir que la dificultad de este juego es el mas sencillo de la saga (tomando en cuenta el mamut del 3 y las zonas del 5), pero eso no quita lo divertido, de hecho te hace tomarte en serio y recompensarte de la manera correcta en mi opiniÃ³n.
Finalmente este juego tiene dos cosas malas; una siendo que no hay razones reales para pasÃ¡rtelo varias veces mas que los logros, habiendo podido tomar la libertad de crear mas desafÃ­os o meter los jefes 2.0 en la campaÃ±a normal, finalmente el reto de daÃ±o que hasta 30 billones; es un reto que te obliga al rejugar para subir de nivel y conseguir comida que te aumente stats. Seria un gran juego para platinar si no fuera por esas tres medallas, pero si no lo planeas un juego mas que recomendado.

review:

Es simple, estilo de RPG por turnos bien clÃ¡sico, pero igualmente te engancha. Es muuuy adictivo

La historia dirÃ­a que es mÃ¡s simple todavÃ­a, no es muy atractiva pero funciona.

En cuanto a dificultad, tiene momentos muy dificiles. Cada que avances mÃ¡s vas a tener que ir cambiando de equipo de forma casi recurrente para aprovechar debilidades enemigas, habilidades extra, etc. 

Recomiendo jugarlo en dificil o Ã©pico, el juego termina siendo mÃ¡s estratÃ©gico de Ã©sta forma. En mi caso, engancha mÃ¡s :)

review:
This game is AMAZING! The gameplay got better thanks to several QoL updates since the EBF3 days, and the story is just... 10/10! All 4 protagonists are completely unlikable morons, and I LOVE them for this! The whole game makes fun of modern-day [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3134182429]people[/url], [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3134180859]companies[/url], world and society in general.

10+ years later, and it's still getting updates!

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3134171422]They don't make games like this anymore[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561199122343742', 'num_games_owned': 21, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1698496197}
review:
loves these flash games, they were fun and were funny
full of dumb jokes and references
if you like to play an rpg that has you actually think about your actions and not spam overpowered sh- and at the same time have you turn off your brain and enjoy a story thats funny, dumb, but not boring, and also has puzzles that require some brain power but not enough to make you sit there for 10 minutes feeling like you have brain damage, this is the game for you.
on one hand your saving the world, the other your making a pc for konata izumi from lucky star.

anyway, this guy makes good chill games that have your brain on -30% cpu usage but in a good way. you know the devs chill when he lowkey roasts people who play on ez mode

author: {'steamid': '76561198141723141', 'num_games_owned': 182, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1910, 'last_played': 1704495425}
review:
Ahhh, the nostalgia of flash games. This is basically just the flash version, but with an assortment of extra goodies. The art is very 00s/10s flavored and the gameplay is similar to EBF3, but this time you have a 4th character in the back line you can tag in. If you want to ignore this mechanic, you are free to do so, but it is available as you wish. It's a standard Turn-Based RPG very inspired by Final Fantasy (complete with limit breaks). You can change the difficulty of your game at any point which affect damage multipliers and enemies getting additional buffs on the harder difficulties. A neat feature for when you want to challenge bosses at full power but don't feel like dying to Overworld enemies.

It is by no means a perfect game, the progression feels odd and heavily reliant on having your gear at max levels (lvl5 for weapon/armor and lvl3 for trinkets) with forging materials being accessible in material shops throughout the lands. A bit anti-climactic when I acquire a new weapon and I can't use it right away because the stats are pitiful at lvl1 which usually means a trip to the store where I buy black matter for 300,000 euros and MAYBE I can get my weapon to the proper level.

This is especially troublesome because elemental properties are applied to most things and serve as the core of your offense/defense. Equipping a max level weapon with an elemental affinity grants you 50% resistance to that element which can be supplemented with armor to gain immunity and drain to certain elements. And it becomes crucial in the late game to have SOLID defenses.

Buffs and Debuffs are also very important because they increase your stats up to 70% and the damage as you progress through the game becomes very high. I'm actually yet to beat the final boss because my party members are taking over 50% of their health WITH A 70% DEFENSE BUFF to certain attacks. With the revival item being very easy to purchase, you can expect to just spam revives and slowly attrition enemies down (if you can survive :P)
I'm thankful that level grinding is not something that must furiously be done, but you will reach a point where you can learn more skills than you know what to do with, and those are also kinda trash until you have them leveled significantly.

I've spent 30 hours in the game, partially for my nostalgia for this series and because this is a serviceable game. I've had my fair share of frustrations with it, but it is a neat, albeit flawed, experience. I haven't even gotten into how absurd the dialogue is at points and the fan service and how distasteful some secrets are. Just know what you're settling in for.

review:
classic turn-based strategy where you take on 4 characters that you can fight with.
it's not just about shooting blindly and using mana, you also have to think about what you actually want to do on harder difficulties, every wrong spell = death.
Along the way, you collect clothes, weapons, things to improve, and of course you kill enemies along the way.
I thought the boss from 3 was hard, this boss gives me goosebumps, hard af
Very good game recommend and please stop killing my  Anna.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035954788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 9104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9100, 'last_played': 1703453004}
review:
I've played the games of this series a good number of time over the years. I'm currently doing a 100% run of the game again and despite the many times I've played this one in particular it is still as fun as I remember it being all those years ago when it was released on Kongregate and other flash game websites.

For anyone who is a fan of turn based RPGs I highly recommend this game now that the 2.0 has fixed most of the performance issues. It has both interesting challenges, and an in depth turn based combat system that is rather unique compared too other games I have played. Just note that as of the time I am writing this review you have to go to the game properties in the Steam client, select Betas, and select version 2 in order too opt into the 2.0.1 version. Also, the developer has talked about a potential 3.0 update releasing for this game, so if you do pick this game up, keep an eye out for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050336410', 'num_games_owned': 744, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 278, 'playtime_at_review': 1610, 'last_played': 1711839372}
review:
[h1] An Epic Adventure Full of Fun and Charm! [/h1]
[h2] Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… (5/5) [/h2] 



I absolutely loved Epic Battle Fantasy 4 on Steam! The game captivated me from the very beginning with its charming pixel art style and humorous storyline. The battles were incredibly engaging, and I loved the strategic element of choosing the right skills and equipment for each character.

The game offers a wide variety of enemies to battle, each with their own unique abilities and weaknesses, which kept me on my toes and made every encounter feel exciting. The boss battles were particularly challenging and satisfying to overcome.

What I appreciated most about Epic Battle Fantasy 4 was the amount of content it offered. There were a plethora of quests to complete and secrets to discover, which provided hours of gameplay. The game also allows for a lot of customization with the ability to level up and upgrade skills, as well as find and equip different weapons and armor.

The soundtrack in Epic Battle Fantasy 4 was fantastic and perfectly complemented the gameplay. The catchy tunes added an extra layer of enjoyment to the overall experience.

Overall, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 on Steam is a fantastic game that I highly recommend to both RPG and indie game fans. The charming art style, engaging battles, and abundant content make it a truly enjoyable and satisfying gaming experience.



[b] -Like Final Fantasy, but a Flash based game, a upgraded version of EBF 3. [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198119074091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 9460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9460, 'last_played': 1698108505}
review:
Beware, this review contains spoilers and therefore I don't think you should read it before completing the game once.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------



I've followed this series since ye olden flash days, I adore it, enough to have revisited for a third epic playthrough.
(Handicaps: Natalie got heal+heal more+ revive and I never used her) 
The gameplay is strategic and engaging, the characters are oddly endearing love-letter parodies of fantasy/anime caricatures.



Matt, the swordsman shounen protagonist. 
Natalie, the straight-man mage to Matt's idiocy, note that she is very aware of the male gaze.
 Lance, the perpetually horny weeb edgelord gunsman who somehow owns a tank+nukes?
Anna, the single-minded archer who jumps to conclusions, magically attuned to nature.

Their skills tell you who they are, if it wasn't already clear enough.

Matt can summon swords of fire, earth, and ice but no matter which one you choose, his swords are the swords that will pierce the heavens. Lines of dreams and hope, be they from the living or dead form the edges of his blade. That is Tengen To-
Oh shit, is that Band*i entertainment and studio Tr*gger at my doorstep?

Natalie is the prude of the party, Her most powerful skill is judgement which is holy but she's got them dashes of goth in her nature with her pulsar. When she's not either, she uses fire, thunder, and ice to deal with her opponents. Oddly enough, the same elements as her red dress's resistances. And if you look closely at said dress, there's an extra 'feature' at the......oh who am I kidding? You probably already have the pervert achievement. (As do I.)

Lance is the embodiment of the people who own that achievement. He's got eyes everywhere, including the back of his uniform. He owns a tank, nukes, and a ton of bots that he uses for ''surveillance'' and ''scouting'', most certainly never on Natalie nor Anna. Spoiler alert, Natalie knows. Oh yeah, his skills? Ehhh, he uses a lot of AOEs that alternate between physical and magical. He covers the elements of blast/bomb, thunder, dark, fire, and a pretty good poison infliction.
NGL, he's a jack of all trades , master of none.
 
Anna is the master of single-target damage/status effects. 
So single-minded, her arrow can headshot harder than Lance's bullet.
Having been attuned to nature, her arrows signal the earth and plants to smack or poison her foes.
And then.....I have no idea how her arrows can form a bubble, multiply+ freeze enemies, eletricify, or smites her foes.
But if there's one thing I do know, she starts with the precursor skill to gaia seed. A skill that is OP bc it inflicts tired.

Status effects, a quick rundown of my impressions of all of them

Brave- New addition, was not in EBF3, not gonna say what it does bc matt starts with temper
Bless-Good for preventing status ailments and instant death
Regen- Extra healing. Need I say more?
Poison- Barely used it
Burn- Same as poison
Tired- Powerful
Cursed- I used the weapon effect flair for it, really strong when your enemy takes nearly 2x dmg from your attacks
Weaken- Barely used it as most enemies have no particular weakness to holy damage
Berserk-Losing control of your character is never a good idea
Wet- Broken when used with thunder/ freeze
Freeze- Very OP for small fry


Equipment- This is where I have a real bone to pick. During my recent revisit, I only used the character set of Anna,Matt, and Lance.

The girls have equipment that covers the entire spectrum of elements. The aforementioned red dress is very strong bc it covers three elements. Then the pope armor covers holy and dark. Their viking armors cover ice, water, and wind.
They're pretty much fully geared for every fight in the game including the final boss.

But the guys? They get a viking helm which does cover ice and wind BUT it randomly grants berserk to the wearer, basically taking away your control. And they have only one armor-piece that resists holy( which also doesn't give a boost to DEF or M.DEF). 
Their dark resist armors only cover earth as an extra. 

Because of all of this, I had to gear up Matt to be an Omega tank while Lance got most of the elemental resistances from the armor+ Flairs. If there is one saving grace for the final boss fight, it's that the guys get the spacesuit set, of which each piece gives +40% more DEF+M.DEF. 
By the end of my run, Matt had most of the DEF/M.DEF stat foods and +90% DEF/M.DEF from equips. Also funneled all the evade stat boosts into him.

Summons-most of them are bad bc the effects are weak or they're just a big elemental AOE. 
This is fixed in EBF5 where summons are used more as party buffs/ status effect set-ups.
My favorite summons were ice sprite after I used rain, slime bunny for regen, monolith for party defend, big robot for atk boost.

author: {'steamid': '76561199282406482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1690108388}
review:
But only at a great discount***

I loved playing all the EBF games on Kongregate back in the day, and I'm very happy to see them uploaded to steam.

I still find EBF 4 enjoyable, I love the exploration and the upgrades. I never found the story or dialogue engaging, and I still don't, but I can click through all that. I can't say the humor has aged well (you know the sort of cringy internet humor we had as teenagers back in 2011, with the keks and teh lulz), but the mechanics of the game are engaging enough that I can ignore that. 

What I can't ignore, though, is the performance. I'm playing this on a high end computer and it lags even at the lowest settings. At some point, the game caused a flicker on one side of the screen, which persisted for the rest of the day. The day after posting this review (which is why I've updated it), the game crashed completely.

Because of these issues, I can only recommend it at a low price. I paid about $5, and I'm still a little miffed tbh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198226345020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4156, 'last_played': 1710170412}
review:
Even though it's not quite as good as its successor in terms of its gameplay, it still has some elements that by far outshine not only the other games in this series but also other games in the JRPG genre.

Characters (9/10):
As expected of this game series, the protagonist and deuteragonists in [i] Epic Battle Fantasy 4 [/i] are written excellently. They have so many great lines, and their idle animations show off a ton of flair and personality. Also, the primary antagonist is possibly the most logically consistent of her kind, and despite her relatively limited screentime, she proves to be a force of personality that is very welcome. However, there are a few weak points. The character kits in this game are slightly less defined than in its successor game; Lance and Anna can sometimes feel like they share too similar of a role. Also, the NPC dialogues are quite bland and lacking in flavor.

Gameplay (8/10):
An upgraded version of classic JRPG gameplay that still maintains the essence of what makes turn-based combat so great. Sadly, [i] Epic Battle Fantasy 4 [/i] does suffer from a lack of balance that can often be found in other games of its genre, namely the fact that healing and defensive skills are far too overpowered. However, it makes up for this by including many strategic elements like the summon system, the weakness and resistance system, the gear system and the tactics system (all of which are seen in the next installment); these systems give strategic richness and complexity that many other games of this genre lack. Add in some elements of puzzle-solving, and exploration and you have the makings of a very solid JRPG.

Art (9.5/10):
The art and music in [i] Epic Battle Fantasy 4 [/i] is near perfect. As expected of a game that was released nearly a decade ago, though, some of its visual assets and animations do feel slightly dated, but the game can hardly be faulted for this. Every piece of equipment is designed thoughtfully and with great flair, and all the battle sprites and animations are smooth and pleasing to look at. The music of this game needs no champion; it is so self-evidently excellent that I feel there is nothing I can say that will do this game's music justice.

Story (10/10):
This is where [i] Epic Battle Fantasy 4 [/i] eclipses its successor. The story starts out simply, with the heroes enjoying the fruits of their labors after the last installment; however, they uncover a secret plot to summon an ancient goddess and once again happen to find themselves responsible for protecting humanity. The character development is natural and authentic, as the characters meet a fourth party member who was at first disliked; yet, as the characters mature through the storyline they grow to respect one another and develop a palpable camaraderie. The progression of the storyline is logical and the world-building is flawless; all of this builds up the anticipation for what is undoubtedly one of the greatest final boss fights ever crafted. Every second of this game's finale was filled with grandeur and brilliance in a way that is very memorable.

Although it perhaps is not as great as [i] Epic Battle Fantasy 5 [/i] in terms of the game itself and overall polish, it is undoubtedly a strong predecessor with the best story in this series. Absolutely worth playing, alongside its sequel [i] Epic Battle Fantasy 5 [/i]. 

Final Score: 36.5/40 (Phenomenal)

review: As someone who never played this series when they were originally released - but did play many RPGs of a similar generation - this is shockingly good. On the surface it's a silly parody of Final Fantasy-type games, but the gameplay is actually really well done. You can tweak the difficulty to your liking, on the hardest setting you'll find tactical challenges worthy of any SNES classic. The humour is enjoyable too, for anyone who remembers the internet in the 2000s.

author: {'steamid': '76561199004037687', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2165, 'last_played': 1681724840}
review:
I want you to look at that play time and know that this is me, almost 40 hours into this, and Im barely at the final boss on the highest difficulty level. For a budget indie game sequel to a set of hyper budget early 2000s era flash titles, this game is amazing. It shockingly holds up to scrutiny even nearly 10 years after release, having solid quality of life, game balancing, and enjoyable dialogue. If you like the classic flash style of game, but want something a bit more robust, or just really like old fashioned jrpg combat and want to really have an experience that emphasizes what the genre is good at, then i can't recommend this enough. 

Honestly, though get the collection, EBF3 is decent on its own, and im sure the sequel to this improves on its design further, and its very cheap for how much content you're being provided.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031991603', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1276, 'last_played': 1582154539}
review:
EBF4 is a traditional RPG, full of quests, locations to explore, loot, characters, and tons of enemies and summons. The graphics and humor bring back memories of playing Flash games for hours on end - this game is a joy to play and is totally confident and unashamed of its roots.

Any RPG fan should play this game, and the whole series. To use a single word, this game is full of soul. It's JRPG distilled down to its most basic form, and despite being a distinctly western game it nails the genre perfectly. Combat is smooth, loot feels important, and the cast of characters never gets old. It doesn't take itself seriously, and you shouldn't either, but you should definitely play this game if you've ever enjoyed a JRPG.

review:
Pretty much my personal ideal for an RPG
characters are enjoyable without being too deep, story fits the goofy nature of the characters and the soundtrack is incredible
The achievements add some replayability to the game as beating bosses on the hardest difficulty on a first playthrough can be incredibly difficult as they seemed (to me at least) to be designed around having a decent chunk of stat boosters that wouldn't be available without the ng+ (or maybe I'm just bad)
Also Lance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198410102021', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1479, 'last_played': 1675807987}
review:
This RPG has all the fun stuff of RPG's together, without all the boring parts.

[b]The cool things:[/b]
-Damage types and matchups.
-Secret chests.
-Lots of skills and summons.
-Lots of equipment with different types/skills.

[b]The removed boring things:[/b]
-No need to farm for anything.
-No overly complicated story, and all character dialogue is fun.
-HM's (hammer, candle, etc.) are not annoying.
-No random encounters or tall grass.

Also, the music is great, and the presentation is quite polished.

review:
I enjoyed this game for the first few hours and even pushed through a few hours more to at least beat it. I am too bored to play this further and beat it. What is first a simple game continues to be a simple game. There is nothing inherently wrong with a simple game if there are many simple things to do. But there is one thing to do in this game and that's the same battle over and over again while the characters talk about the other characters boobs. 

Not worth at any price.

author: {'steamid': '76561199061381792', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10942, 'last_played': 1669699962}
review: If you've play ebf3, you are just getting more, but better. I've had quite a few playthroughs on this, and i'll probably have quite a few more. It's a great turn base rpg with a fun art style. It offers a whole lot of challenge on the higher difficulties, but it's worth it in my opinion. Only gripes I can think of is, much like ebf3, it was a product of it's time, and some of the dialogue hasn't aged well now adays. But other than that, I recommend you play it.

review: Great game. I have played through it multiple times and even welcomed the Version 2.0 update. I still have fond memories of Version 1.0, especially the massive difficulty spike. Call me a masochist if you want, but having to be wary of bosses being able to one-shot you after a certain level made each victory all the more satisfying.

review: played this game years ago and going back to play premium version is very satisfactory. The story centers around finding the three jewels to avoid waking up the cat goddess that will bring the end of the world or smth, they fail to do so and end up fighting her and somehow winning. What i like the most in this game is the music, some equips and leveling to very high levels and taking on superbosses. Overall graphics and difficulty are ok and i like superbosses being strong. Excepcional music especially premium ones. My note is 9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198384465596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 14615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2333, 'last_played': 1710508366}
review:
I first picked up this game Because i read a review that it was astonishingly better then Toby Fox's Undertale.
I was skeptical and admittedly bias because i love undertale, however this game won my heart. 
I personally do not like it more then undertale but that was primarily for biased reasons and primarily because undertale is iconic to me as a person, its my mario, my zelda, my... whatever. 

However, through game play, through story, through funny moments, and through being meta, this game is a game i have grown quickly fond of and i completley understand and respect ANYONE who thinks this is better then undertale. one of the best video game's ive played in years, and that was only version 1. you can opt into a version 2 beta for more features. 
HIGHLY recommend to anyone who knows their way around an rpg and has played undertale.

Edit (12/10/2022)----
Tips for New Players: Several Status effects can increase Elemental Damage. I didn't know the wet status effect increased ice damage until Recently, so read carefully when you can. 
On harder difficulty's and with set challenges in the V2 Beta version of the game, Rafflesia Can be a pain, And its most exploitable Weakness will be Ice. you can also find a plethora of strategies that may or may not work for you on a wikipedia for the fandom. 

I had gotten stuck on Rafflesia but with some help from a discord server, And a bit of my own idea, i was able to beat it on epic difficulties and max challenges. Afterwards, though it took a few hours, i was able to immediately get back into the groove of the game despite not playing for a month and running on a very minimum Amount of Sleep. Still Recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993566959', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1034, 'last_played': 1684982392}
review:
Despite this being a flash game (I think), it's actually a very long, thought out, and engaging RPG. It is a typical turn based RPG with 4 characters (3 usable at any given time). There's plenty of strategy with your typical buffs & debuffs, as well as elemental damage. Plenty of skills & gear to upgrade as you go through the game as well as cross-character skills. Plenty of small puzzles and backtracking through new ares of old zones for higher level loot. While the main story doesn't have me on the edge of my seat it definitely is interesting enough to keep me playing.

Overall, gud game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983119595', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 3179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3179, 'last_played': 1654576188}
review: This is a decent old school rpg. There is zero story and mostly exists for the elemental combat a la Pokemon. The main problem is the software the game was built on is unstable. The game would stutter and lag after about 30 min of play. It can be remedied by closing out of the game completely and relaunching it which will then give you another 30 mins of smooth performance.

review: Like Epic Battle Fantasy 5 so much that i had to go back and play the older EBF games. Combat is still very engaging and the game encourages players to try out different kind of build. The game also has many quality of life features that modern rpgs need to have. And anyone planning to play this game be sure to access V2 in the beta section, it features even more quality of life upgrades and gameplay balancing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198842048066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2267, 'last_played': 1668460626}
review: I love all of the EBF games. I played 1&2 on the web and fell in love when I fell into EBF 3. It's a very cool dungeon crawler, with a thrilling but not too heavy story line. The game is full of references to the games in its own series as well as childhood favorites that bring a much welcome sense of nostalgia. For the full effect of the story and references I recommend starting with 1&2, which are not the same as 3,4 and 5, they're just turn based battles with increasing difficulty, but even they have some very cool content that is touched on in the later games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202024306', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5347, 'last_played': 1709483216}
review: Great game with plenty of humor. Breaks up old "Hit it until you die" gameplay in the genre by making buffs and ailments important! Seriously though, it's like SMT in that regard, some enemies on the harder difficulties will one shot characters consistently if you don't take time to set up defensive buffs and debuff their attack. In fact, enemies are intelligently designed to use clever strategies, like one getting the party wet so the electrical/icy monster can tear them a new one. Monsters are also creative, and even monsters of the same family are given distinct detail. Equipment's also fun to use, as while they change your elemental properties and stats, they're multipliers, not straight adjustments, meaning that your starting equipment is just as valid an option as the stuff found at the endgame, also averting the JRPG trope of "Ultimate Equipment" in a fun way. You can even "Forge" the stuff to upgrade their multipliers and add new effects! Bosses are also tough on epic difficulty, but not unfair, and you can always scram to regroup and try again from the top! Also, the game's free on Kongregate and other sites if you have a flash player that still works, but this paid version adds extra gravy to an already amazingly designed package.

author: {'steamid': '76561198273996318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1645170082}
review:
Ignore my 3 hours, I have much closer to 100 on Steam, and I can't even pretend to know how much I played on Flash. This game... This game means so much to me. It's not a perfect game, and it's definitely from 2014, but this game raised me. Matt shaped my humor. Natalie forged my love for history and books. Lance got me into coding and game-deving. And Anna shaped my taste in women (:>). While there are objective flaws with the game, IE a teleportation glitch, and while there are some balancing issues, this is, and probably will always be, my favorite EBF game, and probably my favorite RPG.
This ****'s better then Undertale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094027153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 13613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13102, 'last_played': 1644445813}
review:
Game Review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a turn based RPG, inspired by many classic games including final fantasy and pokemon. It's full of pop-culture references, from anime to music and movies. The combat system is well developed. Battles are a huge part of the game. It greatly improved on its predecessor's mechanics, adding a whole host of statuses and resistances. Skills unique to each character and specials that can be learned by several party members added to the variety in combat decisions. Not to mention having a 4th character, so the main party can switch between backup and frontline members. EBF4 might not have added any new elements, but there are many more skills that fill in the gaps left in EBF3. Water and wind attacks were unbelivably low.
Don't get me started on the music. Phyrnna knocks it out of the park every time. Who knew a single person with mostly MIDI-type soundtracks could produce better music than 98% of soundcloud. I can't say it's perfect. It's clear that the sound files get a little too compressed in-game, an unfortunate sacrifice. :(
No Epic Battle Fantasy review could be complete without mentioning how HILARIOUS it is. And not in a jarring way either. Serious moments are pretty serious, but the game is very light-hearted. There are plenty of cheeky 4th-wall breaking moments. The comedy is all very in-character for them, and doesn't get overused. The characters grow as the game goes on. It's subtle, but noticable. And they've definitely changed as characters as the series as a whole has gone on. It's easy to make a likable static character, but they're not. and Matt makes it work really well. I should have stopped this review 15 minutes ago and I'll just keep going unless I stop now lmfao

Story:          7/10 
Gameplay   8.5/10
Characters: 10/10
Music:         9/10

Love note:
I've been a fan of Matt's work for years. I still remember the very first time I found one of his games. It was Epic Battle Fantasy: Adventure Story. You should check that one out, it's an adorable platformer. I loved it and on the title screen there was a link to Epic Battle Fantasy 3. And so my love grew. I played each release, including the lesser known works, like the mech builder game, and the original no-legs game. This was while Epic Battle Fantasy 4 was still in development. I remember drawing fanart in 4th grade of your swords, and predicted that a ninja would be the next character. I was really sad to not have the money to buy the premium version of EBF4 way back then. Once EBF5 was in the works, I would check in often. I was so excited! When it finally came, I waited for a sale and tried to get my hands on a coupon for it, unsuccessfully. Once I did get the money for EBF4 and 5, it's safe to say I was a very happy lad. Mostly because I got to support one of the coolest indie game-developers ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198391983907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1688974235}
review: I found this game series is super fun and i would recommend you guys to play it also

author: {'steamid': '76561198146711524', 'num_games_owned': 73, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 191, 'playtime_at_review': 1935, 'last_played': 1711807749}
review:
il 3 mi ha accompagnato per tanto tempo come gioco flash per tanto tempo da piccolo e, una volta visto in bundle su steam, non ho potuto resistere alla tentazione di comprare il 4. Mai denaro fu meglio speso: se il 3 Ã¨ una divertentissima parodia dei classici rpg con un'interessante storia e gameplay con, tuttavia, una moltitudine di problemi di bilanciamento, il 4 prende tutto ciÃ² che il suo predecessore ha fatto bene, lo fa meglio e rivela davvero pochi difetti. piÃ¹ di una volta i dialoghi mi hanno fatto piegare dalle risate e ci sono una moltitudine di references che fanno molto piacere. ciliegina sulla torta il finale che per qualche motivo che non mi spiego mi ha fatto ridere di gusto. Unico piccolo problema: durante le sessioni di gioco piÃ¹ lunghe mi sono ritrovato a dover chiudere e riaprire il gioco per evitare un forte lag che mi impediva di giocare
Per questo prezzo la roba da fare Ã¨ davvero tanta soprattutto se, come me, ti piace girare ogni singolo anfratto prima di andare avanti. consigliato al 100% e non vedo l'ora di mettere mano al 5; grandi aspettative per quello

author: {'steamid': '76561198014370466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1626782970}
review:
I have no idea what is going on. Literally no clue.
But I DO like this game more than any of the Final Fantasy Games release since FF7 (original, not that weird remake that looked nice but was dull and had boring, overly complex but meaningless dialog).
Not mad keen on the "jokey" sexism and portrayal of women (grow up lads) but it's still cute, fun and dumb enough to keep you entertained.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098474981', 'num_games_owned': 52, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1687110991}
review: Just like EBF 3, it's an amazing adventure to play through. All EBF games are, but EBF 3 and 4 especially. Can you imagine just one guy making all of this? This was all done just a single, passionate game dev and his musical composer. That is amazing to think about. The Epic Battle Fantasy games feel much more personable that way; and impressive, considering all the content thats packed in this awesome game. I think this series deserves more recognition and support!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060103454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1892, 'last_played': 1653891422}
review: This is a damn lovely game that doesn't piss about with angst or seriousness. It's fun, lighthearted, and sometimes stupid as hell. And that's why I love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993531522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 347, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1629195685}
review:
It's baby's first JRPG... but in a good way. 

A cartoon-based, fast-paced RPG that will satisfy anyone who wants a more quick-fire experience than the fluff and time-wasting bloated dialogue that you have to put up with, with practically every other JRPG out there. Not exactly deep but it follows the same turn-based formula in a more easy-to-understand form.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269126001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1347, 'last_played': 1639420470}
review: I bought this on a whim, but it is an awesome, funny and enjoyable jrpg. It takes about 20 hrs to finish, so it's on the short side, but the game is worth the money they ask for it. The real star of the game is the way you level up skills and forge equipment. There are so many options for how you can build your party, and it happens at a good pace that keeps it interesting. I find myself getting bored 3/4 through a lot of rpgs, after the leveling up slows down, but with this game you feel like you are always progressing and getting stronger. I knew nothing about this game franchise and started with 4, and I was worried about that, but it hasn't affected my enjoyment at all. It just took a minute to learn how to navigate the game and menus, but overall it's pretty intuitive and absolutely worth a play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198281166439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2642, 'last_played': 1693018543}
review:
I have played the game in my childhood as a browser game. Playing it again as a full version was such a great nostalgia-trip, I cant recommend this enough!

12/10

review: Ce jeu est mon jeu d'enfance sur pc, j'y ai jouÃ© et rejouÃ© sans m'en lasser, je reviens toujours dessus avec grand plaisir. Les graphismes ont l'air simple mais ils sont bien fait et adaptÃ© au style de jeu, c'est mignon et drÃ´le a la fois, le gameplay est satisfaisant avec beaucoup d'actions intÃ©ressante a produire, des tactiques et des interactions bien foutu, la durÃ©e de vie dÃ©pend vraiment du joueur et elle est plutÃ´t bonne pour ma part. Les personnages sont attachant, les rÃ©pliques marquantes, et les ennemis classe. Rien a redire mÃªme si je peux manquer d'objectivitÃ© face a ce jeu, il a bel et bien ses dÃ©fauts, mais je pense clairement qu'il a suffisamment de qualitÃ©s pour satisfaire la plupart des joueurs nouveaux ou non et qu'il justifie amplement les 10 euros. Incroyable !

author: {'steamid': '76561198137548791', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 650, 'last_played': 1633935384}
review: A relic of a time left behind us. The game is a fun and lighthearted romp through different areas to defeat bosses, collect gear, and fight enemies. Filled to the brim with jokes, references, and silliness. The equipment is numerous and varied, and nothing becomes obsolete. From armor to weapons to trinkets, everything has its own unique quirks that alter your playstyle and elemental matchups, and everything you can equip is rendered visibly on the characters. There are so many unique enemies, and each boss has its own strategy rather than just being a "hit it till it dies" or "hit the weakpoint after it attacks" style boss. From the wonderful music, the nostalgic artstyle, and classic humor to the variety in equipment and enemies themselves, this game is truly a masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070808999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 11711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10148, 'last_played': 1681874468}
review: I love this game, although admittedly it is nostalgic for me so I'm probably biased. I first played this game on Kongregate, but this, the Steam version, has quite a lot of extra content like new optional boss fights and equips. I really like how the gear and battle systems in this game emphasize buffs, which in other series often don't feel that impactful. The different party members also have enough unique to them for them to all be useful depending on the situation, so none of them feel like just better or worse than the others. I like the humor here, and the cute felt style for the cutscenes. I'm attached to the characters, though again, nostalgia is definitely a factor. I think the game is a lot of fun, and if you've played the web version and liked it, the new content in the Steam version is worth the money.

review: Effectively a direct upgrade to EBF3, this game has everything it had and more. A better pacing with bits of the story revealed throughout the adventure, a fourth character to add an extra layer of planning to the combat, and decent comedy to boot. You won't be disappointed buying this game if the third game, free on Steam, was to your liking. This further marks a tradition of each sequel being better than the last game in every way, even maintaining that wonderful music by Phyrrna.

The gameplay is classic turn-based RPG, and the story is your average RPG fair as well. (So far, it's been 'collect x thing = save the world') It's the characters and the super fun NPCs and background art that keep me playing. Always some new video game reference to find in towns and dialogue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198354511979', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4524, 'last_played': 1649358110}
review:
Is this a good game? Yeah, it is, I wouldn't have gotten full achievements if it wasn't (especially considering how tedious it was to beat the game three times (ngl just switched it to Zero difficulty on the second two playthroughs, wasn't dealing with the final boss three times on Epic). If you're done with EBF5 and want a bit more EBF action, I'd recommend going down the line and taking on this one next.

However, make no mistake, between EBF3's stellar difficulty curve and general difficulty and EBF5's extremely well thought-out battle mechanics, I'd say this is probably the worst of the trilogy. It's difficulty is very touch-and-go, with most fights even on Epic being a cakewalk then Mighty Oak comes in and makes you grind out a whole extra level to take ONE of its attacks. The stat curve between levels in this game is the most intense, and especially when it comes to bosses it makes the experience curve favor grinding above all else. Unlike EBF5, there aren't a lot of level-scaling areas, so the experience curve sticks with the player through basically everything. The game as a whole is also balanced more around needing buffs as opposed to having them, at least on Epic difficulty, and the limits on recovery and safety when compared to EBF5 really makes momentum required. As a result, battles drag on, and whenever you lose it completely ruins morale. Also, elemental variety on individual enemies is extremely limited, even compared to EBF3, so usually a battle either has too many elements and can 2-or-3 hit you constantly or you can absorb the enemies' attacks. A bit of a shame, really.

Although, there are a few battles that despite these flaws STILL feel amazing. Full-game spoilers, in case people care about that.
[spoiler]Godcats do NOT mess around, they're easily one of my favorite single fights in the series. They're paced surprisingly well, especially considering the final phase is just both of them at once, even then though that phase itself makes a few concessions that make it extremely well balanced even WITH that, and honestly I can't praise it enough. Also, the Evil Twins rematch was great, instant heart attack looking at Evil Lance and Evil Anna coming out at the same time, and the fact that the Twins were all structured like a puzzle to begin with makes combining them even more technical. But yeah, I got my s#$% kicked by those fights and the game is better for it.[/spoiler]
The satisfaction I got from beating the game on Epic was incredible. While the story isn't anything special, the difficulty of the game made it much more engaging, as if I'm actually facing an onslaught of monoliths.


Also as a side note, I updated to 2.0, which singlehandedly improved the game a significant amount, even the small QoL things like swapping without needing to use the tactics menu really helps but that's besides the point. When I updated the suggested solution didn't work for transferring saves, and I was too stubborn to request a replacement, so I had to basically re-beat EVERYTHING (I had reached the top of Battle Mountain and everything) just for, like, 10 medals. I'm definitely not salty about it if you couldn't tell. Anyway, play this after EBF5 if you still want more EBF.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072270271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 5623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4080, 'last_played': 1613182875}
review: I sure would recommend this game, especially with the V2.0 update out now in beta and its rebalancing and QoL stuff.  The EBF series is great games but they ramp up in quality and strategic depth with each installment.  EBF4 has 4 playable characters and is the last game to keep using an MP system, while EBF5 has 5 playable characters and much stronger abilities for them all... but no MP system and instead rigid cooldowns with stronger moves having many turns of CD before they can be used again.  I've got to be honest, after playing 5 it was kinda hard to go back to 4 for this update, but this game is still really something special.  The music is amazing, the bonus bosses in Battle Mountain are still hair-pullingly difficult, and this game will make you reevaluate every other RPG you play because you'll ask: "Why doesn't this FF or DQ game use common sense and have this system work like it does in EBF4?".  Always a good game to replay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198443886491', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1405, 'last_played': 1611029234}
review:
Absolutely incredible that this is the work of a single developer. After playing EBF3 for years in the browser, the death of flash finally convinced me to buy EBF4 and it is worth every penny. The game is so much more in depth than EBF3 and really rewards clever uses of buffing, debuffing, and status effects. Playing to completion (or as close as I could get to finding all the secrets) is not overly grindy and actually provides useful equips and skills. Only downside I see is a memory leak, so I would recommend saving and exiting every 2 hours or so.

EDIT: memory leak was apparently patched

author: {'steamid': '76561198060986520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2473, 'last_played': 1529460314}
review: Do not expect a very elaborate story from this game, but it is still a lot of fun to play. The very simplistic combat system actually hides a necessity to truly play on your strengths and optimize your party using the ridiculously high amount of equipment found along your way. Although far from being a game of the year, I found it to be pleasant and satisfying of my need for non-sensical stories and not too bright characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202139988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 752, 'last_played': 1672873089}
review:
This game, oh boy, this game.
You know, I used to play the flash version of this game and the one before it too.
I loved exploring around, killing all the enemies there were just so I could scan those enemies to get achievements.
I went looking for achievements on these games just so I could feel like I was playing the game.
The ability to change difficulty doesn't seem to make things too easy or too BS(well maybe sometimes), I tend to play on the hardest difficulty so I usually get fights that make me enjoy fighting enemies while the music played.
The bosses are true challenges that made me think of plans to defeat them quicker!
I always liked looking for things to make my team stronger and richer, so I looked around for treasures and hidden objects, and they're quite well-done. 
I love these types of games, they're wonderful.
The challenges are actually challenging and not just too-insanely-difficult-and-requires-a-ton-of-luck(most!)
The soundtrack is very great, I love hearing the very battle-like battle themes and the very open-world overworld themes.
The story is intriguing, and had me on it's hook.
I'd recommend this game to any fan of these types of games, it's quite a good game.
note; I might have a bias because it's kinda nostalgic to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118950984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 5741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5741, 'last_played': 1601397206}
review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a logical step in sequence after the third game and a obvious precursor to the fifth.  While I have copious nostalgic memories of the third and fourth games, I think the game itself earns its accolade on its merit alone.

Surprisingly, EBF4 adds a lot to the tactics of the turn-based battle that the third game did not really have.  The interesting status effects, the different abilities of the equipment, the extra player, summons â€” all contributed to a more fleshed-out mechanic.  It certainly added some difficulty when achievement hunting.

Apart from the battle mechanics, the map layout was also something notable.  It is obvious that the concepts of secret areas and intermediate locations permeated into the fifth game well, but it was surprising to revisit this game and realize it felt like more than just a flash game.  The nonlinear sections like the graveyard were neat, and the optional areas were even better.  While it still felt a bit haphazardly thrown together, Battle Mountain was great as well.  Again, the fifth game further improved upon these; in EBF4 these sorts of areas do not feel like their own areas.  They really feel like "bonus" areas for extra content rather than built-in dungeons, but that is only a minor criticism, as I enjoyed playing through them anyway.

The humor is to be expected â€” it is what makes that game charming.  The plot is near nonsensical and does not take itself seriously.  It is as much an EBF game as it gets.  I would definitely recommend this game to anyone that wants a cool JRPG-style game with lots of content for a relatively cheap price, because that is exactly what this game is.  I loved the game years ago as a flash game, and EBF4 is still a good game today.

author: {'steamid': '76561198167032869', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 10824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10824, 'last_played': 1601533741}
review:
Nearly six years. 
That's how long it took me to beat this thing.
I bought EBF5 with the coupon and haven played it beyond the loading screen, for fear that the experience would be similar to Paper Mario 64 vs. TTYD, where once I got used to the latter, I didn't want to downgrade. 
I've seen the worst this game has to offer, from stupid super plants (yes, THAT upgraded boss), spammy status effects (including but not limited to insta-death, stun, and syphon), a final boss I COULDN'T beat with any strategy (even including Anna), giving up and grinding an extra two levels to make it a joke, and at it's worst, (3 times this has happened) the game straight up not saving to the files and forcing me to redo parts I just completed after restarting. 
If you think I recommended this game on accident, remember I came back, time and time again to beat this thing. That counts for something, and it isn't just spite. 
No, I didn't go at this for six years STRAIGHT. I took breaks that lasted months each because I stopped playing and forgot about the game entirely the next day. Definitely my fault, but if I went at the hardest challenges this game had to offer 5 years ago, I'd probably have double the hours I do now. 
Most of these complaints are just from the end-game, since I really don't remember the rest of it that clearly (I beat Rafflesia in the story back in 2015 according to my achievements, take that as you will). I think I had fun at the earlier parts, with the difficulty not making the game impossible, but difficult enough to be fun. 
The final boss was exclusively harder than the rest of the game due to being at level 33, as the damage multiplier from the difficulty is applied twice once above level 32, increasing the bosses damage output from 2x to 4x the normal amount while on Epic. With the party at level 32, this fight was practically impossible, even after finishing all Battle Mountain had to offer. I grinded for bigger numbers, killing the zombie hydra until I was level 34 because I wanted to make sure no single mistake (or bad RNG) could end my entire team in one turn. 
When I returned to the game in August (this year), I found out I just happened to be at the perfect level for Battle Mountain, level 32, as that whole quadruple damage thing wouldn't apply until one level later. Of course, this didn't mean I was in for a FUN first battle upon returning, as it was the plant, and the plant was only weak to wind, had healing, a OHKO rainbow beam, and tiny versions of itself. Of course, after this, Battle Mountain was an actual fun experience, the enemies guarding chests being reasonably difficult for the extra hard area they were in, the dark players being a, strange change of pace, but ultimately bringing a good challenge. 
Then there were the marathons. The monster marathon wasn't really challenging until the pseudo-mini bosses appeared (those being enemies with immunities to stun, syphon, and freeze), with the dragons specifically being the scariest part, while the river squid, limit break in hand, came in a close second. The other three marathons each gave a good challenge, but remember that I kept Anna on backup until the team got wiped, making the game that much easier. I had to redo the upgraded boss marathon because of the aforementioned "game not saving" glitch, of course I knew it wouldn't be more difficult to do it a second time, but man, bosses having limit breaks really puts the hurt on you. 
The dark player marathon. two bosses, at once, each can heal if they FEEL like it, which gives them bless on top of extra health, meaning their biggest weaknesses, poison and fire, couldn't be inflicted for like 4 turns. On top of that were the limit breaks. This means the dark player marathon is the area for Anna's third highest time on screen, with the second being desperate strategies with the final boss, and the first being the beginning of the game. (Seriously, she had to go through a bunch of lines when I tried to use her with the final boss.) The dark players limit breaks being an important factor, due to being able to use so many, made deciding whether to attack or buff more important. Do I attack with Matt, buff the party's defense, give auto-revive, or buff Matt's attack for next turn? Sure, I ask these questions to myself with every boss, but the answer isn't as obscured in those as it is in this fight, where I can reference one dark player's health to another to estimate how close they are to their next limit break, and act accordingly. 
The endless battles was more RNG dependant than anything else, I got wiped on wave 30 by a dark dragon the first time and had a laughably easy time with a giant slime and two satellite towers, as the giant slime ISN'T immune to stun, and the towers are only partially immune to syphon. 
There's also an ultimately minor problem of refunded specials, as you don't get the points back once you do so. I put a bunch of buff specials on Matt and made it through the game despite this, so the only important factors of the fights were in my playstyle and strategy. RNG was important too, but that's a given in this game. 
One last question. 
Who the am I writing this for? It isn't people who want to buy the game, because most of what I remember is from the end-game and Battle Mountain. It's not for people looking through reviews, because who's looking through a several year old games reviews? In the end, this rambling is only for myself, because this game has left me annoyed, the final boss being a disappointment in both character and difficulty, that being impossible a level under and easier than expected a level above. Sure, if I knew that at level 33, I probably could've won by the skin of my teeth, I would've stopped there, but the only expectation I had was quadruple damage to the party. I can't help but compare it to Battle Mountain's challenging but possible fights. Hell, the fight may have been difficult, party members died plenty of times, and Anna even had to come out of backup once, but it never felt like I was in actual danger of a game over. After level 34, it took me two tries to beat the final boss, with the first one being ended early from the game freezing. Maybe that's just how much better I, or rather, my strategies became because of Battle Mountain, but I don't know. Maybe I was (and still am) just too tired to fully realize the difficulty, but I do know that I underestimated Matt's damage output, as while crits and the RNG in general weren't on my side, Matt was making his way through the final boss's health faster than I expected. 
If, for some reason, you want an actual review:
The best way to play, for me, is on Epic and to strategize accordingly, using armors that protect against your enemies' elements. The difficulty is part of the fun in and of itself, as one of the benefits of turn-based combat is how you have the time to choose your next action. Always take the alternate path or guarded chest, the reward is usually worth it. Make sure you stop yourself at level 32 for your biggest advantage at Battle Mountain, not having to deal with quadruple damage on Epic. 

I should REALLY get to playing EBF5 soon....

author: {'steamid': '76561197996273719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 798, 'playtime_forever': 1511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1511, 'last_played': 1599312650}
review:
[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is an action role-playing game developed by Matt Roszak.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

In Epic Battle Fantasy 4 you have to control a group of fantasy heroes - together with their legless cat - through an exciting story. What initially appears after a hunt for the thieves of some stolen crystals turns out to be a mission to save the world as the story progresses. The legendary god cat once created the cats as ruling people - humans as their servants. Players must now prevent the Godcat from being awakened with the help of the stolen crystals. On their way they have to endure a lot of turn-based battles against large and small enemies as well as powerful bosses. In the best RPG manner, you have to take care of equipment and skills management, put experience points into new skills and use the respective strengths of the various heroes in a tactical manner. A total of over 140 different items and 130 different skills and spells are available.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ exciting story
+ good scope
+ Anime-style graphics
+ coherent soundtrack
+ many weapons and equipment are available
+ Achievements and trading cards

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- Boss fights are sometimes difficult
- bad keyboard layout

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Epic Battle Fantasy 4 offers turn-based battles and a cute anime look that is reminiscent of classics like Final Fantasy. Clear buy recommendation.


[h1] Information / Review Deutsch [/h1]

Epic Battle Fantasy 4 ist ein Action-Rollenspiel, welches von Matt Roszak entwickelt wurde. 

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

In Epic Battle Fantasy 4 Es gilt es, eine Gruppe Fantasy-Helden â€“ zusammen mit deren beinloser Katze â€“ durch eine spannende Story zu steuern. Was anfangs nach einer Jagd auf die Diebe einiger gestohlener Kristalle erscheint, stellt sich im Laufe der Geschichte als Mission zur Rettung der Welt heraus. Einst erschuf die legendÃ¤re Gottkatze die Katzen als Herrschervolk â€“ Menschen als ihre Diener. Dass die Gottkatze mithilfe der gestohlenen Kristalle wieder erweckt wird, mÃ¼ssen Spieler nun verhindern. Auf ihrem Weg mÃ¼ssen sie dazu jede Menge rundenbasierte KÃ¤mpfe gegen groÃŸe und kleine Feinde sowie mÃ¤chtige Bossgegner bestehen. Im bester RPG-Manier muss man sich dabei um AusrÃ¼stungs- und FÃ¤higkeiten-Management kÃ¼mmern, Erfahrungspunkte in neue Skills stecken und die jeweiligen StÃ¤rken der verschiedenen Helden taktisch klug einsetzen. Insgesamt stehen Ã¼ber 140 verschiedene GegenstÃ¤nde und 130 unterschiedliche Fertigkeiten und ZaubersprÃ¼che zur VerfÃ¼gung.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ spannende Geschichte
+ guter Umfang
+ Grafik im Anime-Look
+ stimmiger Soundtrack
+ viele Waffen und AusrÃ¼stung stehen zur VerfÃ¼gung

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Epic Battle Fantasy 4 bietet dir rundenbasierte KÃ¤mpfe und einen niedlichem Anime-Look, das an Klassiker wie Final Fantasy erinnert. Klare Kaufempfehlung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070017864', 'num_games_owned': 119, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1599524187}
review: I have played this on Kongregate back in the day, and payed for it when it came out on Steam. Graphics are pleasant and charming, combat and equipment has a lot of depth and is engaging. There's a ton of room for customizability and grinding, but it is not necessary to win in normal mode. Bosses are creative and challenging, dialogue is quirky and hilarious. The only annoyance I have is the animations are sometimes too long, but that's fine. This game pushes the limit of Flash and is one of the best free Flash RPGs ever made

author: {'steamid': '76561198225570696', 'num_games_owned': 719, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 1723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1699, 'last_played': 1610710388}
review:
Bigger and better than EBF3, if a bit overwhelming sometimes, and with a longer campaign.

The level cap to 30 is gone this time, so I guess it's possible to grind for experience if you don't want to bother with upgrading and changing equipment, optimising the party order and all that.

Though really, it is never required to grind for experience if your strategy is up to snuff.
Just play smart, and have fun!

(It's easy to have fun, as the staple dialogue from NPCs and reactions during battles are here again and as funny/ filled with references as ever.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198136486322', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 5625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5625, 'last_played': 1505366622}
review:
Pra comeÃ§ar, fiquei sabendo da existÃªncia desse jogo apos jogar o Epic Battle Fantasy 3, que esta disponÃ­vel DE GRAÃ‡A aqui na steam, entÃ£o se vocÃª nÃ£o jogou ele ainda deveria jogar!!! O jogo assim como esse Ã© excelente e te darÃ¡ uma boa ideia do que esperar das sequencias. 
Jogo de RPG com batalhas em turnos e mecÃ¢nicas clÃ¡ssicas, com uma enormidade de equipamentos com caracterÃ­sticas e elementos diferentes, elementos que por sinal sÃ£o uma grande parte das estrategias nos combates. Varias habilidades Ãºnicas para o estilo de cada personagem, alÃ©m de avassaladoras habilidades especiais. A principio o grÃ¡fico do jogo pode parecer meio bobo mas nÃ£o se deixe enganar, o jogo Ã© muito divertido. O jogo consegue ter uma postura nÃ£o muito seria, com piadas e referencias a todo momento, sem deixar de ter uma historia interessante e uma jogabilidade agradÃ¡vel.
O jogo nÃ£o Ã© tÃ£o difÃ­cil e vocÃª pode completa-lo de uma forma bem relaxante, alem de conter alguns segredos durante a jornada e modos extras ao finalizar o jogo.
E nÃ£o vamos esquecer de um dos pontos mais interessantes do jogo, vocÃª pode clicar nos seios da personagem principal a praticamente qualquer momento para fazer eles balanÃ§arem!

author: {'steamid': '76561198293411361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2236, 'last_played': 1594341986}
review:
This is my first review, so bare with me.

GAMEPLAY
Epic Battle Fantasy 4, at first glance, just seems like your standard JRPG styled game, but it has very unique ideas that make it stand out. You're able to find (or buy) many types of equipment and upgrade them, giving the character who wears it resistances to different types of attacks or status ailments, so all of the different weapons, armor, and badges you find will be useful in certain areas and battles. There is also a skill-tree system that allows the player to upgrade the different magical abilities given to them and unlock new ones using Attack Points that are earned in battles. Some unlockable skills can be given to one of the 4 heroes (or one of a select few of them) at the player's choice, so each character's set of moves has a layer of customizability. In order to win you have to take advantage of enemy weaknesses with these skills and counter their strengths with your armor. As someone who's played a decent amount of RPGs, there was not a single moment that I found the battle system tedious or repetitive, which should speak volumes for its quality. There was also no times in the game where I felt I was required to grind for levels in order to progress, the enemy balancing was perfect to keep everything engaging while not causing unnecessary level spikes, at least on Normal difficulty. The overworld map is also full of puzzles to solve and hidden chests to find and unlock, which is paced very well with battles. Fights are not encountered randomly, as they are enemies on the world map that are interacted with, and the player can flee any fight anytime they want, both of these are very nice quality of life features. 

STORY/CHARACTERS
The game's story is very simple: get the three gems back and save the world. The story works for what it's going for. The characters are very charming though, all 4 of them have distinct personalities and their dialogue bounces off each other humorously. I really enjoyed the simplicity and carefree nature of the characters and story.

PRESENTATION
The game's art style is overall very simple, but all of the main characters look great. The enemy designs are creative and overall everything just looks very pretty. Frequently, you'll be given art stills over certain cutscenes, which look like they were hand made out of arts and crafts, which I thought was especially cute. A very pleasant surprise though was this game's music. Every track is knocked out of the park here, with some of my favorites being all the battle themes, Ashwood Forest's theme, and the final boss theme.

CONCLUSION
Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is an enjoyable little blast to play start to finish. With charming characters, awesome music, and a deep battle system at an affordable price, there's really no going wrong with picking up this hidden gem. Not only is this a great RPG to start with but it's also perfect for those familiar with the genre.

FINAL RATING: 5 STARS

author: {'steamid': '76561198012363945', 'num_games_owned': 2121, 'num_reviews': 409, 'playtime_forever': 2026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1561, 'last_played': 1642016855}
review:
Can't stand the 'classics' this particular game refers to on its store page but this one is an exception to me and it is designed to perfection. A game that can be (and i have) played in short sessions without losing the plot at any time. I am at the late game stage and i have been playing this game for years in small sessions here and there. 

I can imagine hardcore final fantasy players sneer at this filthy casual game but for my needs it is perfect. may probably be the only game of this type that i play as these games are so demanding on the concentration and time side yet this one has so expansive crafting/upgrade paths that there is always something to look forward to. Always a mission or upgrade to get but without the oh so modern stretched  'forced engagement with the product' that so many bigger titles want you to do nowadays. As said i have played this on and off as small sessions here and there and never lost where i am. 

So i suppose i recommend this. As long as you know the difference between a more hardcore experience and a more casual  like this one. Hard fights here as well but we are not even close to the frustrations i experienced a long time ago with Final Fantasy 7. I don't have time for that bs anymore. Life is too short. Don't want to 'engage with the product' too much when not needed. I could hardly care if ever finish this but at least i already know i have had a good run. Something that Final Fantasies never provided towards the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007792308', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 2258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1140, 'last_played': 1700283470}
review:
UPDATE: My review and my execution of user One Piece Was A Mistake was so angering to Kupo707 that he shat out a new update as a "i'm totally not mad guys haha!" Let it never be said that my rebellion against all attempts to control me is ineffective.

Flash games and retail games are two very different beasts. The former is expected to be janky compared to commercially available (non-AAA) games. and "so bad it's good" most of the time. The latter is where you expect to get your money's worth. Funnily enough, I paid nothing for this port of a flash game and I still feel ripped off.

Kupo707 always had a few problems with his style of development. When he's not searching VGcats for jokes to steal, he's busy being unable to stop doubling down on awful design decisions. Whether it's making health regenerate by walking to a point where it's a viable strategy to do something else in another window between fights, or deciding that the new original lesbian druid archer (who is a totally good idea to add shut up don't criticize me t. probably kupo) needs to be the most powerful character in the party for maximum mary sue points, but at least she wants to grab Natalie's jugs haha so epic am I right fellow gamers?

To get back on track; Kupo707 cannot grasp the concept of "dialing back." It seems that he looks at every awful idea from his previous games and says "I really, really need to double down." The combat system is proof of this, given how it was flawed from EBF1, i.e. the very beginning, and he still cannot make it tolerable once you look past the new weapons and skills to use. It's just such a slog, as if he saw the memes about PSX JRPGs having overly long battle animations and said "that's a great idea! Let's make this nigh-worthless attack have a cool satellite beam animation for SWAG! what do you MEAN, people didn't like that repetitiveness?"

All that, and the fact that he cannot grasp the concept of what I call "skill bloat." See, the big gimmick of EBF, aside from awful mid-2000s video game webcomic dialogue, is the AP system. You got a list of skills that you can buy in almost any order, with some weaker skills unlocking newer ones. See the problem? There's dump skills that are there for no reason besides "I need to inflate the AP economy, goy!" For christ's sake, Etrian Odyssey and 7th Dragon handle this problem relatively well, you have the template for how to make your game's skill system suck less RIGHT THERE.

In all frankness, I'm not kidding about paying nothing and feeling ripped off. I was given the EBF bundle as a very cruel gag gift, and I hope that the gifter can pull the mother of all cons and get a refund(you know who you are, I believe in your ability to lie your ass off). Turns out that deciding to 100% EBF3, the prequel that's somehow equally worse and better in various areas, was a horrible idea in MANY ways.

But hey, what do I expect from a dev who still thinks GamerGate was anything but controlled opposition. NPC developer, horrible game, 0/10 don't even bother with the flash version holy shit why would anyone pay money for this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169773485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2392, 'last_played': 1577530655}
review: It's a funny and kind of cute turn-based RPG with a nice plot line. Nothing complicated, but it's not completely unoriginal. I played Epic Battle Fantasy 3 for a bit and this one is certainly an improvement. Controls aren't clunky and graphics are a bit nicer. Combat gets a bit boring once you get to the point where one fight takes over fifteen turns, but that's to be expected. I enjoyed the light-hearted humor. You should enjoy it if you enjoy other RPGs.
